source.65623b51:
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
%matplotlib inline
import seaborn as sns
source.3caf851d:
g = sns.displot(
    data=df, kind="kde", rug=True,
    x="culmen_length_mm", y="culmen_depth_mm",
    col="island", hue="species",
)
source.9aa4974d:
g = sns.displot(
    data=df, kind="ecdf",
    x="body_mass_g", col="sex", hue="species",
)
source.5ed4eb2d:
sns.histplot(
    df, x="culmen_length_mm", hue="island", element="step",
    stat="density", common_norm=False,
)
source.7f86e3ea:
The dataset consists of 7 columns.

* species: penguin species (Chinstrap, Adélie, or Gentoo)
* culmen_length_mm: culmen length (mm)
* culmen_depth_mm: culmen depth (mm)
* flipper_length_mm: flipper length (mm)
* body_mass_g: body mass (g)
* island: island name (Dream, Torgersen, or Biscoe) in the Palmer Archipelago (Antarctica)
* sex: penguin sex
source.50f51447:
![](https://miro.medium.com/max/1000/1*gM_WIfx7MXOO7jzsPm-Y0Q.png)


A major release of Seaborn visualisation library came out in September 2020 and this release came with some very important new features and enhancements, their official logo being one of them. Yes, S[eaborn now has its own proper logo.](https://seaborn.pydata.org/citing.html)


In this short notebook, I present new distribution functions introduced in Seaborn 0.11 along with examples. 

Detailed information on the changes introduced : https://seaborn.pydata.org/whatsnew.html#:~:text=v0.-,9.0%20(July%202018),and%20some%20notable%20API%20changes.

For an overview of the new features and a guide to updating, see this [Medium post](https://medium.com/@michaelwaskom/announcing-the-release-of-seaborn-0-11-3df0341af042)

This notebook has been adapted from both the sources above.
source.788ec631: ECDF plots are a statistical technique that facilitates quantitative comparisons between distributions:
source.e967497c:
# Depricated Functions

The `distplot()` function is now formally deprecated. Its features have been subsumed by `displot()` and `histplot()`
source.32653e5d:
# New plotting functions

## displot()

This function provides access to several approaches for visualizing the univariate or bivariate distribution of data, including subsets of data defined by semantic mapping and faceting across multiple subplots. The kind parameter selects the approach to use:

* histplot() (with kind="hist"; the default)

* kdeplot() (with kind="kde")

* ecdfplot() (with kind="ecdf"; univariate-only)

Additionally, a rugplot() can be added to any kind of plot to show individual observations.
source.ee6a3782:
## ecdfplot()

An exdfplot plots empirical cumulative distribution functions.
source.6d7be3ce:
## histplot()

A histplot plots univariate or bivariate histograms to show distributions of datasets.
